items.title: Australia defeats words with actions to complete rapid Ashes romp
items.description: In the pre-series furore, with England crowing and injury concerns mounting, Australia stayed quiet. Its response has been an emphatic and quite brilliant Ashes domination.

items.title: Putin picked Steve Witkoff as Trump’s Ukraine envoy, WSJ says

featured_image.name: Putin Meets With Witkoff and Kushner for Nearly Five Hours

items.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin personally orchestrated the selection of Steve Witkoff as his preferred American interlocutor, using Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman as an intermediary to engineer the billionaire real estate developer's rise as a key envoy in negotiations over Ukraine, according to a Wall Street Journal report published Friday[1][2][3].

The revelation comes as Russian envoy Kirill Dmitriev arrived in Miami on Saturday for continued peace talks with Witkoff and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, marking the latest round of negotiations aimed at ending the nearly four-year war[4][5][6]. Dmitriev told reporters late Saturday that the discussions were proceeding "constructively"[3][6].

items.title: Five quick hits: Ponting slams 'dopey' England star as Lyon goes down
items.description: Jamie Smith is pilloried as "a dope" after an ugly dismissal as Nathan Lyon is injured and Marnus Labuschagne creates more catching magic. Here are the quick hits from day five of the third Ashes Test in Adelaide.

items.title: A Reddit user proved vital in locating the Brown University shooting suspect
items.description: On December 13 a gunman killed two Brown University students and wounded nine others, escaping by foot.

items.title: US strikes kill at least five IS members in Syria, monitor says
items.description: The operation employed more than 100 precision munitions targeting known IS infrastructure and weapons sites, according to a US Centcom statement.

items.title: Satellites document year of space breakthroughs and global events
items.description:
From 250 miles above Earth, satellites documented a year marked by both cosmic breakthroughs and terrestrial upheaval, while spacecraft ventured closer to the Sun than ever before and international crews maintained humanity's quarter-century presence in orbit.

High-definition cameras aboard satellites captured 2025's most significant global events with unprecedented clarity, from the Los Angeles wildfires that scorched over 50,000 acres in January to Pope Francis' funeral procession through Vatican City in April[1][2][3]. The European Space Agency's Copernicus Sentinel-2 mission recorded smoke billowing from the Palisades Fire near Santa Monica on January 7, while Landsat satellites revealed burn scars across the greater Los Angeles area through spectral imaging that distinguishes healthy vegetation from charred landscapes[4][5].

items.title: At least 16 Epstein files disappear from DOJ website

featured_image.name: Available to download Friday, some Epstein files no longer there Saturday afternoon

items.description:
At least 16 files disappeared from the U.S. Department of Justice's public webpage for documents related to Jeffrey Epstein less than 24 hours after being posted Friday, with no explanation from the government and no notice to the public, according to reports from the Associated Press and NPR[1][2][3][4].

The missing files, which were accessible Friday and no longer available by Saturday afternoon, included a photograph showing President Donald Trump alongside Epstein, Melania Trump, and Epstein's longtime associate Ghislaine Maxwell, as well as images of artwork depicting nude women[2][5][6]. The photo, labeled file 468, showed a desk drawer containing multiple photographs, with Trump's image among them[7][8].

Democrats on the House Oversight Committee pointed to the missing Trump photograph in a post on X Saturday, writing: "This photo, file 468, from the Epstein files that includes Donald Trump has apparently now been removed from the DOJ release. @AGPamBondi is this true? What else is being covered up? We need transparency for the American public"[1][5][8].

items.title: 'The dream is over' as England falls short of another heist
items.description: Ben Stokes laments the end of England's Ashes "dream" as Australia wins the third Test by 82 runs on a surprisingly tense final day to take an unassailable 3-0 series lead.

items.title: Ancient interstellar comet emits first-ever radio signal

featured_image.name: You can still see comet 3I/ATLAS in the night sky. Here’s how.

items.description:
An ancient traveler from beyond our solar system completed its closest approach to Earth early Friday morning, as scientists confirmed the first-ever radio signal detection from an interstellar object.

Comet 3I/ATLAS passed within 168 million miles of our planet at approximately 1 a.m. EST on December 19[1][2][3], offering astronomers a rare glimpse of material that may have originated in the thick disk of the Milky Way billions of years before our sun formed[1]. The comet, discovered in July by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System in Chile[1][4], is only the third confirmed interstellar visitor ever detected, following 'Oumuamua in 2017 and Borisov in 2019[5][6].

items.title: Images removed from Epstein files less than a day after being posted
items.description: At least 16 Jeffrey Epstein-related files, including a photo of US President Donald Trump, disappear from a US Department of Justice webpage within a day of being posted, with no explanation.

items.title: Crowds gather at Bondi and around Australia for a minute of silence at 6:47pm
items.description: In a nationwide memorial, Australians will take a moment this evening to light a candle and quietly remember the 15 people killed at Bondi. Their names, stories and legacies are held close by a shaken, grieving community.

items.title: Retirement dreams shattered after paying $84k for a never-built house
items.description: Multiple people are speaking out about their experience paying too much to a building company for work never delivered.

items.title: 'Another level of betrayal': Survivors search the Epstein files to find nothing
items.description: Despite giving an FBI interview and victim statement, Epstein victim Jess Michaels finds no trace of her evidence in the vast trove published online.

items.title: Scientists measure electrical flow in matter hotter than sun

featured_image.name: SLAC researchers measure how materials hotter than the sun's ...

items.description:
Researchers at the Department of Energy's SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory have developed a contactless technique to directly measure electrical conductivity in warm dense matter, an exotic state found deep inside stars and planets, according to a study published in Nature Communications[1][2][3].

The breakthrough, announced by SLAC on December 17, comes after nine years of work and could help scientists better understand planetary magnetic fields and improve nuclear fusion experiments[4][5][6].

items.title: Who's named in the Epstein files and who else was he connected to?
items.description: The Epstein files offer another glimpse into the financier's vast network of wealthy and influential figures. Here's what we know about his relationships with some of the world's most powerful people.

items.title: Lula urges EU to finalize Mercosur trade pact in January

featured_image.name: EU delays trade deal with South America’s Mercosur bloc as farmers protest

items.description:
Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on Saturday called on the European Union to demonstrate "courage" and finalize a long-delayed trade agreement with South America's Mercosur bloc, after the deal's signing was postponed to January following fierce opposition from European farmers[1][2][3].

Speaking at a Mercosur summit in Foz do Iguaçu, Brazil, Lula urged EU leaders to move forward with the pact after more than 26 years of negotiations[1][3]. "Without the political will and courage from leaders, it won't be possible to finish a negotiation that has dragged for 26 years," Lula told his South American counterparts, who gathered on the border with Argentina and Paraguay[2][3][4].

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had planned to travel to Brazil on December 20 to sign the agreement, but the ceremony was canceled after France and Italy demanded more time to secure stronger protections for their agricultural sectors[1][5][6]. Multiple European diplomatic sources confirmed the signing is now targeted for January 12 in Paraguay[5][7][8].

items.title: Space milestones and Earth monitoring define 2025
items.description:
As 2025 draws to a close, the year stands as a landmark period for spaceflight achievements and humanity's ability to monitor Earth from orbit, with developments ranging from an interstellar visitor's approach this week to quarter-century celebrations of continuous human presence in space.

This Friday, December 19, marks the closest approach of interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS to Earth[1][2][3][4][5], the third known object from beyond our solar system to pass through our cosmic neighborhood. Discovered on July 1 by NASA-funded ATLAS telescopes in Chile[1][4], the seven-mile-wide comet has been tracked by multiple space agencies and observatories, including NASA's Parker Solar Probe, Hubble Space Telescope, and JUICE Jupiter probe[1][2]. The comet will pass approximately 170 million miles from Earth[6][1] before continuing its journey back into interstellar space, never to return.

items.title: Ancient interstellar comet makes closest approach to Earth

featured_image.name: View Interstellar Comet 3I/ATLAS Through NASA's Multiple Lenses

items.description:
An ancient interstellar comet made its closest approach to Earth on December 19, marking the culmination of a year in which space-based observations revealed both cosmic mysteries and terrestrial catastrophes with unprecedented clarity.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, the third confirmed interstellar object to pass through our solar system, came within 168 million miles of Earth as it continued its hyperbolic trajectory toward the outer solar system[1][2]. NASA coordinated an unprecedented observation campaign involving Parker Solar Probe, the James Webb Space Telescope, and Hubble, capturing detailed data from the ancient visitor that may be older than our solar system itself[2][3][4].

"The data that will come down from the spacecraft will be fresh information about a place that we, as humanity, have never been," said Joe Westlake, director of NASA's Heliophysics Division[5]. The comet, discovered July 1 by the ATLAS survey in Chile, exhibited a prominent ion tail as it passed perihelion on October 29 at 1.36 AU from the Sun[2][6].

items.title: Palo Alto Networks Integrates Vertex AI for Real-Time Threat Analysis
items.description: The cybersecurity giant is migrating its key workloads to Google’s Vertex AI platform to leverage Gemini models for faster automated threat detection and governance [web:5].

items.title: Australia Sanctions Two Russian Dark Web Services and Operators for Cyber Attacks
items.description: The Australian Government, with UK and US allies, has sanctioned two Russian men and their companies, Media Land LLC and ML.Cloud LLC, for enabling cyber attacks including DDoS, malware, and ransomware against Australian targets[3].

items.title: Sanctions on Russian Cybercrime Providers Targeting Australia Imposed
items.description: Australia imposes financial and travel sanctions on Media Land LLC, ML.Cloud LLC, and individuals Volosovik and Zatolokin for supporting cyber incidents like ransomware and DDoS against Australian businesses[5].

items.title: Interstellar comet and black hole discovery cap year of lunar landings

featured_image.name: You can still see comet 3I/ATLAS in the night sky. Here’s how.

items.description:
An interstellar comet streaked past Earth today while new observations of a distant black hole confirmed Einstein's century-old predictions, punctuating a year that saw humanity land on the Moon, deploy advanced satellites, and peer deeper into the cosmos than ever before.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, discovered in July by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System in Chile, made its closest approach to Earth on Friday at approximately 168 million miles from our planet, according to NASA[1][2]. The ancient visitor, possibly more than 7 billion years old, marks only the third confirmed interstellar object to pass through our solar system[2][3]. NASA's Parker Solar Probe captured observations of the comet between October and November, while the James Webb Space Telescope conducted follow-up observations in December[4][2].

Just days earlier, astronomers announced the first clear detection of a black hole twisting spacetime itself. The phenomenon, called Lense-Thirring precession or "frame dragging," was observed through a synchronized 20-day wobble in both X-ray and radio emissions from tidal disruption event AT2020afhd[5][6][7]. "This is a real gift for physicists as we confirm predictions made more than a century ago," said Dr. Cosimo Inserra from Cardiff University[8].

items.title: Ancient interstellar comet sweeps past Earth with unexplained nickel emissions

featured_image.name: You can still see comet 3I/ATLAS in the night sky. Here’s how.

items.description: An ancient visitor from beyond our solar system swept past Earth early Friday morning, offering scientists an unprecedented opportunity to study material forged around a distant star billions of years ago. Comet 3I/ATLAS, the third confirmed interstellar object ever detected, came within 168 million miles of our planet at approximately 1 a.m. EST, according to NASA[1][2][3]. While posing no danger to Earth, the comet's unusual metal emissions have left astronomers scrambling to explain its peculiar chemistry.

items.title: ASD Updates Guidelines for System Hardening
items.description: The Australian Signals Directorate releases December 2025 guidelines for system hardening as part of the Information Security Manual, aimed at large organisations and government[4].
